section.title: Introduction
section.para: Differentiate between event-based and continuous simulation approaches, and introduce the three different event-based methods relevant to ARR guidance. Broadly describe how event-based approaches use IFD relationships and storms of specific duration, and the different degrees of sophistication used to accommodate probability-neutrality in the transformation of design rainfalls into design floods. Differentiate these approaches with concepts used in continuous simulation.

section.title: Simple Event
section.para: Describe the simple design event approach (as used in ARR87), its strengths and limitations, the implicit assumption of probability-neutrality involved in the selection of fixed design inputs.

section.title: Ensemble Event
section.para: Describe the use of ensemble approaches to accommodate variability in temporal patterns, and link to evidence where this has been shown to be valid. Describe its application to losses and the problems of including further inputs with non-linear behaviour; summarise the strengths and weaknesses of the approach.

section.title: Monte Carlo Event
section.para: Describe the use of Monte Carlo approaches to accommodate variability in key factors, the use of unconstrained and stratified sampling schemes, and the need to consider dependencies between inputs. Differentiate between accommodating natural (aleatory) variability as distinct from parameter (epistemic) uncertainty. Outline the need to use frequency analysis or Total Probability Theorem to derive design estimates for unconstrained and stratified schemes, respectively. Summarise the strengths and weaknesses of the approach, focusing on its use to handle joint probability of factors involved in the rainfall-runoff process.

section.title: Continuous Simulation
section.para: Highlight the different concepts involved in the use of continuous simulation approaches compared to event-based approaches. Discuss the different model structures involved, the different style of climatic inputs required, its implicit treatment of joint probability factors, and the need for frequency analysis to then derive design flood estimates. Summarise the strengths and weaknesses of the approach, focusing on its applicability to the modelling of complex volume-dependent systems.

section.title: Hybrid Schemes
section.para: Discuss the use of hybrid schemes in which continuous simulation models are used to accommodate the joint probabilities between soil moisture (or water levels in a cascade system) and rainfall sequences at a coarse time step, then their use of an event-based model to simulate flood generation at a finer time-step. Discuss the difference in model structure and climatic inputs, the implicit treatment of selected joint factors, and the need for frequency analysis to then derive design flood estimates. Summarise the strengths and weaknesses of the approach, highlighting the lack of extensive experience with these techniques.

section.title: Worked Examples
section.para: Include a worked example that illustrates application of simple, ensemble, and MC approaches to generation of a rainfall-based flood frequency curve, and compare to results from flood frequency analysis to observed maxima.
